Award.AwardTitle: Impact of Nonmigrating Tides on the Thermospheric Energy Budget and Constituents
Award.AbstractNarration: This project aims to delineate and understand the impact of non-migrating tides on parameters important to the aeronomy of the ionosphere-thermosphere system, such as constituents, infrared emission rates and the thermospheric energy budget. Non-migrating tides are pervasive and known to occur in neutral winds, temperature, neutral density, and ionospheric parameters such as plasma densities and electric fields. They manifest themselves in longitude and local time variability, which recent observations from ground and space have shown to be significant. Based on these new findings, significant non-migrating tidal variations may also be present in thermospheric composition and in the infrared emission of energy to the lower atmosphere and to space. This variability will affect the ionosphere-thermosphere system in various ways, including its photochemistry, energy budget, and neutral-plasma coupling. The investigation will examine the tidal variability in [O]/[N2] column density ratio and in nitric oxide and carbon dioxide volume emission rates of energy, connect it quantitatively with the tides in temperature and winds and provide an assessment of the relative importance for neutral-plasma coupling and the thermospheric energy budget as function of season and solar cycle. Towards this goal, the project will synergistically employ data from the GUVI and SABER instruments on the TIMED satellite and an existing, observation-based model of temperature and wind tides in the thermosphere. GUVI will provide the [O]/[N2] column density and SABER nitric oxide and carbon dioxide volume emission rates of energy emitted at 5.3 microns and 15 microns, respectively. The project will support a Ph.D. student and involve summer undergraduate students in the research. Non-migrating tides largely originate in the troposphere as heat is released by evaporation and condensation near the surface. The effects to be investigated are thus a measure for the geospace response to tropospheric weather and how energy and momentum are transported from the lower into the upper atmosphere. The study will provide observational constraints for an important neutral-plasma coupling process, tidal [O]/[N2] variations, that is predicted by current mechanistic and first principles models. It will provide first insight into the weather impact on Earth's "natural thermostat", the nitric oxide 5.3 micron emissions, by which heat and solar energy are efficiently lost from the thermosphere to space and to the lower atmosphere.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main scientific objective of the project “Impact of Nonmigrating Tides on the Thermospheric Energy Budget and Constituents” (AGS-1112704) is to investigate and understand the impact on non-Sun-synchronous (nonmigrating) atmospheric tides on parameters important to the aeronomy of the ionosphere-thermosphere system, such as constituents, infrared emissions and the thermospheric energy budget. Nonmigrating tides begin near the surface as heat is released by evaporation and condensation in deep convective systems. The tides then propagate upward into Earth’s upper atmosphere and as such transmit the imprint of global-scale weather systems into the space weather of Earth’s ionosphere-thermosphere system, that is, into a region of near-Earth space where most of the manned and unmanned spaceflight takes place. The project objective has been achieved by the synergistic deployment of NASA research satellite (TIMED) data and photochemical/tidal modeling. The project provided fundamental new insight into how energy and momentum are transported from the lower into the upper atmosphere, and how tropospheric weather impacts space weather. The major outcomes are as follows:

 

(i) The study established an observational tidal baseline data set from two instruments on the TIMED satellite (GUVI, SABER), from 2002-2016, and between 100 to 180 km above ground. It has been shown that tides from the lower atmosphere significantly (up to 50%) modulate the energy budget of the thermosphere, in particular the nitric oxide emissions at 5.3 micrometer that act as “Earth’s natural thermostat” by which heat and solar energy are efficiently lost from the thermosphere to space and to the lower atmosphere. A similar result was found for the 15 micrometer emissions of carbon dioxide. This is the first time that the impact of tropospheric weather on the energy budget of the thermosphere has been quantified. Other researchers (general circulation modelers) have already started to use the observational baseline dataset as a validation point for their models. The tidal impact on thermospheric composition (O/N2 column density) has general implications for ultraviolet spectroscopy of Earth’s upper atmosphere as it allows one to better separate signals from the ionosphere and thermosphere.

 

(ii) The physical causes how the tidal signal is transmitted into the energy budget have been identified using tidal/photochemical modeling. The main driver is the temperature dependence of collisional rate coefficients, followed by vertical advection. It turned out that the nitric oxide emission tides are more important during solar maximum compared to carbon dioxide tides, mainly due to the hotter thermosphere. This is the first time that the cause-and-effect chain has been studied in detail and quantified.

 

The observational data sets and physical understanding from the project are important constraints for modeling the space weather of Earth’s upper atmosphere and its predictability, an important task for a technological society. The project resulted in research opportunities for a graduate (PhD) student and three undergraduate students in physics, including training in big data science. The findings have been published in three peer-reviewed articles in top journals, and several conference papers.
